critique: This is an executive order from 1936 exempting a specific person from mandatory retirement. It's a very specific action with limited broader implications. It doesn't touch on immigration, national security, or social inclusion. It has a very slight impact on executive power, as it uses existing authority to make an exception. It has no bearing on federalism or economic regulation. Given the era, it's hard to place it definitively on the liberal-conservative spectrum, but it leans slightly conservative in the sense of maintaining existing structures and norms.
